intro: Quercus arkansana var. caput-rivuli, commonly known as the red oak or black oak, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its deeply lobed leaves that turn red in the fall. The tree produces small, cup-shaped acorns that are an important food source for wildlife. Its bark is thick and furrowed, providing habitat for various insects and lichens. Quercus arkansana var. caput-rivuli typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and can reach heights of up to 30 meters.
